awd_titl_txt: Model studies of chromosome structure and dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
A central question in biology is how the information encoded in a eukaryotic genome is packaged and decoded. The goal of this research is to provide an improved understanding of the structure of a eukaryotic chromosome, and how chromosome structure influences genomic function. A broader outcome will be development of public-domain educational software that will be freely available students over the internet. This software represents an alternative to textbooks for teaching the principles of protein and nucleic acid structure and function, and has the potential to transform the way these topics are taught at the high school and college level. In addition, the project will provide training in research principles and fundamentals at the post-doctoral, doctoral, and undergraduate levels.

This research aims to understand the relationship between chromatin fiber dynamics in vitro and interphase chromosome structure in vivo. Model chromosomes will be assembled in vitro from pure protein and DNA components and used to determine the factors that specify chromosome structure and nucleosome-nucleosome packaging, including the core histone N-terminal tail domains, the nucleosome acidic patch, linker DNA, and chromosomal proteins. To obtain this information, the research will employ a broad experimental toolbox, including fluorescence microscopy to measure chromosome shape, analytical ultracentrifugation to measure chromosome size, and fluorescence recovery after photobleaching to measure nucleosome-nucleosome packaging dynamics. The research is expected to yield data in support of a new, transformative model of interphase chromosome structure and dynamics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Work funded by NSF award MCB-1814012 studied the dynamic behavior of chromatin in vitro and its relationship to the structure and functions of eukaryotes genomes. A reconstituted chromatin condensate model system that recapitulates fundamental properties of an interphase chromosome was used for our experiments. Our studies uniquely bridge the disciplines of biochemistry, molecular genetics, and cell biology and have yielded important new results in two areas relevant to genome biology. In the first, our results were combined with in vivo data from Michael Hendzel’s lab and published in a 2020 Cell paper showing that condensed chromatin behaves as a solid in vitro and in living cells. This work has been transformative by supporting a new model in which condensed chromatin is solid on the mesoscale (100-1000 nm) and liquid on the nanoscale (≤10 nm). The chromatin fiber not only condenses genomic DNA,  it is the substrate for functional processes such as transcription and replication. One of the most ingrained concepts in genome biology is that condensed chromatin is an inaccessible structure.  For over 50 years, functionally inactive chromatin has been described as “closed”, while functionally active chromatin is considered “open”. However, we have found that histone H1, DNA polymerase e and the SirT6 histone deacetylase all can rapidly access and saturate their binding sites in the chromatin condensates. The important ramification of this finding is that the condensed chromatin found in 200 nm chromosomal domains (TADs) in vivo is not functionally repressive and may even facilitate protein binding.  With these experiments we have started to decipher the long sought after basis for how chromatin can simultaneously condense the genome while providing the substrate for functional processes such as transcription and replication. Altogether, our results challenge widely held beliefs and will result in a major paradigm shift in how one thinks about chromosome structure and function. They also have greatly improved our understanding of how eukaryotic genomes are structured and packaged and provide seminal information for all researchers interested in the broad area of genome structure and function. Finally, our NSF-supported research has provided the field with an invaluable model system for studying the condensed chromosomal environment in vitro. For the Outreach project, we successfully converted CD-based Chime tutorials on structural biochemistry into web-based Jsmol tutorials. These tutorials are open access and have the potential to reach a broad and diverse group of students. They will enhance scientific discovery, while promoting learning, teaching, and training.
